headline.main: Brilliance and Promise Will Only Go So Far

results.snippet: EARLY on in ''Fight Club,'' I found myself exulting at the scary wit with which David Fincher was pulling things off and racking up a score. It was like watching some nerveless kid play pinball in a minefield, his body flexed into the machine, his...
results.lead_paragraph: EARLY on in ''Fight Club,'' I found myself exulting at the scary wit with which David Fincher was pulling things off and racking up a score. It was like watching some nerveless kid play pinball in a minefield, his body flexed into the machine, his shoulders and his arrogant hips seeming to drive it into Charlie Parker choruses of bell-ringing. It's a wonder to see such prowess, and in ''Fight Club'' (which opened Friday) I'm talking about not just the creation of some grunge-heaven city but the macabre yoking together of gallows humor and smash-mouth violence, the interplay of Edward Norton and Brad Pitt, nerd and Neo (in the sense of the Keanu Reeves icon from that empty but deeply influential film ''The Matrix''). But this is one of the most glossy and treacherous pieces of cinematic black ice we have yet encountered, with good old photography turning into effects beneath our drifting tires. Then the pinball wizard grows bored with his own brilliance. He turns away, and in one ruinous glimpse you see that he's not just a child but a kind of retard, too. In anything but pinball, he's in his own Alzheimer's.

results.abstract: Interview with Sir Arthur C Clarke, co-writer with Stanley Kubrick of film 2001: A Space Odyssey; he comments on space travel and other matters; photo (M)

headline.main: An Author's Space Odyssey and His Stay at the Chelsea

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: TWO THOUSAND ONE: A SPACE ODYSSEY (MOVIE)

results.snippet: On a recent autumn morning in a suite at his beloved Chelsea Hotel, legendary New York City home of hipsters and artists, Sir Arthur C. Clarke, 81, the author of more than a hundred books of essays and science fiction, co-writer with Stanley Kubrick...
results.lead_paragraph: On a recent autumn morning in a suite at his beloved Chelsea Hotel, legendary New York City home of hipsters and artists, Sir Arthur C. Clarke, 81, the author of more than a hundred books of essays and science fiction, co-writer with Stanley Kubrick of the film, ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' and the dreamer who in 1945 came up with the idea of the ''comsat,'' or communications satellite, held court in a wheelchair tended by his two Sri Lankan valets, Hector and Lenin. The author, who lives in Colombo, Sri Lanka, had stopped off to see old friends and admirers on his way home from a round of medical tests at Johns Hopkins Medical Center in Baltimore.
